metadata.case_name: State of Gujarat v. President, Baroda District Panchayat & Ors. etc.

facts.text: Last election to Taluka Panchayats took place in February 1968 and Panchayats constituted on February 28, 1968. Term due to expire on February 28, 1973.
Five year term of District Panchayats due to expire on March 31, 1973.
By Resolution dated April 12, 1973, State Government appointed high level Committee headed by Jhinabhai Darji to suggest reforms in Panchayati Raj.
On interim recommendation of Committee, terms of Taluka Panchayats extended upto August 31, 1973 and District Panchayats upto September 30, 1973.
Jhinabhai Darji Committee submitted final report on September 30, 1972.
Gujarat Amending Act 9 of 1973 passed, came into force on April 23, 1973. Abolished indirect elections to Taluka Panchayats, provided for direct elections.
By order dated June 21, 1973, terms extended till August 31, 1973 (Taluka) and September 30, 1973 (District).
By order dated October 3, 1973, terms extended upto February 28, 1974 for both. Power under s.17(2) exhausted.
Widespread disturbances broke out in first week of January 1974, public agitation demanding resignation of State Government and dissolution of Gujarat Assembly.
On January 26, 1974, Governor promulgated Ordinance 1 of 1974 substituting 'two years' for 'one year' in s.17(2).
State Ministry tendered resignation on February 9, 1974. President proclaimed under Article 356 assuming State functions.
By order dated February 27, 1974 under amended s.17(2), terms extended upto March 31, 1974.
State Legislature dissolved on March 15, 1974.
Parliament passed Gujarat State Legislature Delegation of Powers Act, 11 of 1974, effective March 27, 1974, vesting powers in President.
President enacted Gujarat Panchayats Amendment Act 8 of 1974, effective March 31, 1974, inserting s.303A.
Notification dated March 31, 1974 under s.303A declaring situation exists due to disturbances, not expedient to hold elections, members vacate office, powers to TDO/DDO for 6 months.
Two writ petitions filed in Gujarat High Court under Art.226 challenging notification by President of Baroda District Panchayat and President of Jamnagar District Panchayat.
High Court by common judgment dated June 26, 1974 held notification invalid as condition precedent not satisfied.
State preferred appeals with certificate from High Court.
Disturbances continued throughout March 1974, loss of life, property damage, agitation for dissolution of Panchayats even in last days of March.
Process of holding elections initiated in August 1973 with proposals for delimitation from Collectors.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Notification dated March 31, 1974 issued under s.303A of the Gujarat Panchayats Act, 1961 is invalid on the ground that the condition precedent to the exercise of the power under s.303A is not satisfied.
Whether a situation existed by reason of disturbances in the State of Gujarat on March 31, 1974 making it not expedient to hold elections.
Scope of 'hold elections' under s.303A(1) - whether includes preliminary steps like delimitation, electoral rolls.

petitioner_arguments.text: Satisfaction of Government as to inexpediency of holding elections is subjective and not justiciable. Only objective condition is existence of situation by disturbances.
Phrase 'to hold elections' should be construed widely to include preliminaries; narrow construction frustrates object of emergency provision.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.303A; canon of construction for emergency measures

petitioner_arguments.text: Disturbances continued in March 1974; efforts to hold elections thwarted; no malice in choosing s.303A over s.17(2) as they operate in different fields.

respondent_arguments.text: Condition precedent of holding elections not fulfilled as preliminary stages (delimitation, electoral rolls, reservation) not completed.
Phrase 'hold elections' restricted to actual conduct from notification to result declaration; preliminaries are prior stages.
Notification based on extraneous reason (expiry of terms) not disturbances; resort to drastic s.303A shows malice.

court_reasoning.text: Two requirements under s.303A(1): (1) objective existence of situation by disturbances (justiciable), (2) subjective satisfaction of inexpediency (not justiciable if reasonable nexus).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Disturbances existed in Jan-Mar 1974, situation continued on March 31 despite abatement.

court_reasoning.text: Situation by reason of disturbances may outlast overt disturbances; sufficient time needed to return to normalcy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Abnormal situation subsisted on date of notification.

court_reasoning.text: Reject narrow view of 'hold elections'; construe widely including preliminaries to fulfil object of emergency provision.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No statutory fetter requiring completion of preliminaries before invoking power.

court_reasoning.text: Notification recital of term expiry is part of situation; dominant reason is disturbances as per affidavits; efforts for elections started but thwarted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No extraneous motive or malice; s.17(2) and s.303A in different fields.

holdings.text: Notification under s.303A valid; condition precedent of situation by disturbances satisfied; inexpediency subjective.
'Hold elections' construed broadly; power exercisable without completing preliminaries.

precedents_cited.case_name: Cannon Street Ltd. v. Singer Friedlander Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Preferred construction fulfilling object of emergency measure over one frustrating it.

statutes_cited.name: Gujarat Panchayats Act, 1961
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to extend terms and emergency dissolution/administration due to disturbances.

statutes_cited.name: Gujarat Panchayats (Amendment) Act, 9 of 1973
statutes_cited.relevance: Abolished indirect elections, provided direct elections.

statutes_cited.name: Gujarat Ordinance 1 of 1974
statutes_cited.relevance: Extended extension power to two years.

statutes_cited.name: Gujarat State Legislature (Delegation of Powers) Act, 11 of 1974

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeals, set aside the Gujarat High Court judgment dated June 26, 1974 holding the notification invalid, declared the notification under s.303A valid.
outcome.relief_granted: Set aside High Court judgment upholding validity of notification.
outcome.costs: Parties to bear their own costs throughout.

key_quotes.text: The situation envisaged by this sub-section, therefore, may not necessarily be co-terminous with the disturbances. It is sufficient if the situation is the immediate outcome of the disturbances, and it subsists.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies scope of 'situation by reason of disturbances' under s.303A.

key_quotes.text: Since s. 303A has been designed to enable the Government to get over a difficult situation surcharged with dangerous potentialities, the Court must construe the aforesaid phrases in keeping with the context and object of this provision, in their widest amplitude.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: We hope that the Government will take prompt measures to hold these elections expeditiously and will not use this judgment as an excuse to postpone the elections indefinitely.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Urges expeditious elections preserving democratic processes.
